Certificate Transparency (CT) is a protocol that ATS can use to identify mistakenly or maliciously issued X.509 certificates. Specifically, CT requires a domain’s server certificates to have support from signed CT timestamps from at least two CT logs trusted by Apple. The system now requires this behavior in all cases, making the key irrelevant.

# NSRequiresCertificateTransparency

**Property List Key**

An obsolete Boolean value indicating whether to require Certificate Transparency.

## Discussion

Certificate Transparency (CT) is a protocol that ATS can use to identify mistakenly or maliciously issued X.509 certificates. Earlier versions of the system used this key to enable or disable CT for a given domain. Specifically, CT requires a domain’s server certificates to have support from signed CT timestamps from at least two CT logs trusted by Apple. For more information about Certificate Transparency, see [https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6962].

The system now requires this behavior in all cases, making the key irrelevant.



## Exceptions

- **NSExceptionAllowsInsecureHTTPLoads**: A Boolean value indicating whether to allow insecure HTTP loads.
- **NSExceptionMinimumTLSVersion**: The minimum Transport Layer Security (TLS) version for network connections.
- **NSExceptionRequiresForwardSecrecy**: A Boolean value indicating whether to override the perfect forward secrecy requirement.
